Poland (Polish: Polska), officially the Republic of Poland (Polish: Rzeczpospolita Polska), is a sovereign country in Central Europe. 
 
 It is covering an area of 312,679 square kilometres with a mostly temperate climate.
 
 With a population of over 38.5 million people, Poland is the sixth most populous member state of the European Union.
 
 Poland's capital and largest city is Warsaw. Other cities include Kraków, Łódź, Wrocław, Poznań and Gdańsk.
The territory of Poland is located by the Baltic Sea, which is located in the north of the country. The beaches are wide and sandy.

With almost ten thousand closed bodies of water covering more than 1 hectare (2.47 acres) each, Poland has one of the highest numbers of lakes in the world. In Europe, only Finland has a greater density of lakes.

In the south of Poland there are mountains, which are taken by the Sudetes and Carpathians. The Tatra Mountains located along the southern Polish border are the highest part of the Carpathians.\n \n The highest mountain in Poland, Rysy at 2.503 m, is located in the High Tatras.
Robert Lewandowski (born 21 August 1988 in Warsaw, Poland) is a Polish association football striker who plays for Bayern Munich and the Poland national football team.\n \n

Fryderyk Franciszek Chopin was a Polish-French composer and virtuoso pianist. He is considered one of the greatest Romantic piano composers.\n \n Chopin was born in Żelazowa Wola, a village in the Duchy of Warsaw.

Marie Skłodowska–Curie was a Polish and French physicist, chemist and feminist. She did research on radioactivity. As a result of her research, she discovered polonium and radium. She was the first person to win two Nobel Prizes.She received a Nobel Prize in physics for her research on uncontrolled radiation.\n \n

Karol Józef Wojtyła, Pope John Paul IIwas the 264th Pope of the Catholic Church from 16 October 1978 to his death in 2005.
 
 He was the second longest-serving pope in history. As a Pole, he was the first non-Italian pope in 455 years.
 He was the first ever pope to visit the White House and a mosque. 
 John Paul II was canonized by Pope Francis on April 27, 2014.

Nicolaus Copernicus was a mathematician and astronomer who formulated a model of the universe that placed the Sun rather than the Earth at the center of the universe.\n \n A polyglot and polymath, he obtained a doctorate in canon law and was also a mathematician, astronomer, physician, classics scholar, translator, governor, diplomat, and economist. In 1517 he derived a quantity theory of money – a key concept in economics.
